description:
We live in an increasingly diverse world! Does your learner have the social-emotional skills to engage in it? There are so many topics related to diversity; where does one start to learn? This course is designed to help your child better understand diversity and themselves as they gain the interpersonal skills and confidence to build diverse relationships, self-awareness, emotional intelligence, and self-care.

We'll start with the concept of intersectionality. That's a big word! Through an interactive story, your child will unpack what this term means and how it plays out in real life. They will also gain valuable skills to practice social justice interventions and better engage in a diverse world.

weeks.title: Overview of Intersectionality
weeks.lesson:
Intersectionality

 Have you heard this word before? What does it
mean? In this lesson, you will learn about this concept and learn to apply it in
real life. The Theory of Intersectionality describes how we all have multiple
identities, such as our experiences, characteristics, race, and economic
status, that interact to inform how we move through the world. Some of our
identities are privileged, and others are oppressed. Intersectionality plays a
role on the individual level, but it is due to large systems of oppression and
privilege that actually cause particular identities to have more or less
privilege and/or oppression. Depending on the unique intersection of one's
privileged and oppressed identities, they will experience more or less power in
a given environment. 

 Before starting on your intersectional journey,
there might be a few words here that you have not heard before. Let's take some
time to define them.  

What is Privilege?

Privilege refers to unearned
benefits that are bestowed upon some and not others because they have
identities that are considered more desirable in a given culture. In other
words, privilege is like a backpack filled with tools. The more tools you have,
the easier it will be to deal with difficult situations that arise. The
situations might still be challenging, but dealing with them will be easier.
Some of us are born with more tools in our backpack than others, making it
easier to do some things. We didn't do anything to earn these tools; we were
just fortunate to have them. An example of one of these tools is not having to
explain your race to others when you are white, which is white privilege.
Another tool is not having to explain why you are attracted to a certain
gender; this is an example of straight privilege. Other people were born with
fewer tools, which can make life more difficult.  

 What is Oppression? 

Oppression occurs when one subgroup has more access to power
and privilege than another subgroup, and when that power and privilege are used
to dominate the other to maintain the status quo (APA, 2022). In other words,
oppression occurs when an identity (i.e., specific gender) has less power than
another identity(i.e., differing gender) due to a system (prejudice) that
delegitimizes (removes respect from) this identity and causes systems and
people to treat us unfairly.  

Whereas privilege is having more tools in your
backpack even though you didn't earn them, oppression is having fewer tools in
your backpack, even though you deserve to have more. An example of oppression
is not being able to read a book you want in the library if you are blind
because the book you wanted is not written in brail.  

Oppression can lead to some of us having a
backpack and some of us having none at all. Additionally, oppression might lead
to having a hole in your backpack. There are many systems of oppression; you
might have heard of some, such as racism, sexism, heterosexism, ableism…  

What is Power?

Power is an invisible force that can provide privilege to some
people and oppress others simply based on their race, gender, or other
identity, that they have no control over. Power can both be a result of
privilege and oppression and can also add to privilege and oppression. 

 Power exists as an implicit force which needs to be made explicit
in order to change it. This means that people with more privileged identities
need to be able to see how they have more power in order to increase
fairness.

scenes.title: Welcome to Intersectional Academy!
scenes.description:
Ms. Jones social studies class settles in for the day. She steps to the front of the classroom beside an African American woman. She introduces her as Law Professor Kimberle Crenshaw, a guest speaker on intersectionality, an important concept related to diversity. Ms. Jones takes a seat, and Professor Crenshaw begins her discussion of intersectionality with the class by reciting a broad definition of the term.

Intersectionality is a lens through which you can see where power comes and collides, where it interlocks and intersects (Columbia school of law, 2017). It is a lens through which we can understand how we all have multiple identities that interact to inform how we move through the world. Some of our identities are privileged, and others are oppressed. Intersectionality plays a role on the individual level, but it is due to large systems of oppression and power that actually cause certain identities to have more or less privilege and/or oppression. Depending on the unique intersection of one's privileged and oppressed identities, they will experience more or less power in a given environment (Case, 2017).

Intersectionality is like the air we breathe, and the wind we feel on our faces. We know it's there, but it can be hard to understand how it operates. The first step in understanding intersectionality is to see it in motion.

options.option: Intersectionality is a term used to describe road intersections.
options.nugget: We're not talking about engineering actual roadways. Try again!

options.option: Intersectionality is a term used to describe the complex ways in which systems of oppression and privilege interact to influence the lived experiences of individuals. This theory states that we all have different identities, some of which are more privileged and others more oppressed. The unique combination of these identities impacts how we move through the world. Well done! #correct
options.nugget: This is correct! The Theory of Intersectionality seeks to explain how we all have various identities that interact with one another to influence the way in which we move through the world.

options.option: Intersectionality is a term used to describe how one identity impacts another.
options.nugget: Nice try here! This is technically correct, however, it is only one part of this theory. There is another answer that better describes the entire Theory of Intersectionality. Try again!

kc.question: Who conceptualized the Theory of Intersectionality?

options.option: Kimberle Crenshaw #correct
options.nugget: Kimberle Crenshaw first coined the term, in her 1989 article, Demarginalizing the Intersection of Race and Sex #correct

options.option: Bell Hooks
options.nugget: Bell hooks is a feminist scholar who also writes on topics including intersectionality, but she is not credited with coining the term Intersectionality. You might want to check out one of her many books, Feminism is For Everybody: Passionate Politics. Try again!

options.option: Brene Brown
options.nugget: Brene Brown is a researcher and author who studies and writes about courage, shame, vulnerability, and empathy. You might be interested in her book, Atlas of the Heart, which describes various difficult emotions we all experience. Try again!

kc.question: Where do systems of oppression, power and privilege originate?

options.option: In the individual
options.nugget: Although we all have different identities that interact in unique ways, the reason certain identities are privileged while others are oppressed is due to larger norms within our culture or systems of power that create privilege or oppression. These larger systems imbue some identities with more privilege and others with more oppression. Try again!

options.option: In the physical environment
options.nugget: Intersectionality describes forces within social contexts that are co-created by social norms. Although these forces will affect how people have access to resources in their physical environment, these forces are socially created. Try again!

options.option: In the social environment
options.nugget: Systems of oppression, privilege and power that privilege certain identities and oppress others are created within the social environment. For instance, we may think more highly of certain types of identities over others due to our socialization or the society around us as opposed to any innate or actual differences between identities. No identity is inherently better or worse, though research has demonstrated that people hold prejudices against particular identities.#correct

scenes.title: Systems of Oppression
scenes.description: Professor Crenshaw explains the term, Systems of Oppression Systems of Oppression are prejudicial systems that serve to devalue some groups of people or specific identities. They tend to take the shape of isms such as: heterosexism, racism, sexism, etc. These oppressive systems cause people with certain identities to have more privilege and also power than those with other identities. Can anyone share a personal example of how a system of oppression has affected them?

kc.question: What is a System of Oppression?

options.option: Systems of Oppression are prejudicial systems that serve to devalue some groups of people or specific identities. Certain identities have less power than others due systems that delegitimize these identities.#correct
options.nugget: Nice work! When an identity has less power than another identity due to a system that delegitimizes this identity, it causes other systems and people to treat us unfairly. Oppression also occurs in very subtle ways. When a majority identity is considered the standard for what is correct, any other group is compared to this standard and will come up short. This is a form of oppression as this is often an unattainable goal. We must first call attention to this assumption to understand its harmful effects.

options.option: It's a body of laws that are enacted by a government to oppress people.
options.nugget: Although laws can classify systems of oppression, an oppressive system is larger than just a law. Laws generally follow oppressive systems, but many oppressive systems operate without a law in place. Laws can actually be used to counteract systems of oppression to ensure more equitable treatment. Try again!

options.option: It is a process by which a group of people create ways to hurt others.
options.nugget: Although this is possible, many systems of oppression are not necessarily intentionally created, but exist due to many sociological, psychological, historical, and cultural factors. Try again!

kc.question: Which of the following is a form of Oppression?

options.option: Bobby was yelled at in class for being disruptive.
options.nugget: There needs to be more information here to understand if he was treated unfairly because of his intersecting identities. Given the information here, it appears that he was reprimanded due to misbehaving, not due to a system of oppression. Try again!

options.option: Bobby was pushed in the hallway because another student was trying to get to class and didn't see him.
options.nugget: This appears to be an accident and thus not a form of oppression. Try again!

options.option: Bobby yelled at another student after he became frustrated that she was not listening to him.
options.nugget: There needs to be more information than what is presented here to understand if this is a system of oppression. It is possible Bobby would not have yelled at this student if she were a boy, which would then be a result of sexism. However, it is unclear from this example. It is also possible that Bobby yelled at this student and would have engaged in the same behavior if the student had been a boy. As such, this is not the best answer. Try again!

options.option: (correct) Bobby was pushed in the hallway because he was wearing pink shoes and another student thought that made him look girly and weak.
options.nugget: This is an example of sexism, a system of oppression that generally devalues women and feminine characteristics. In this example, sexism is operating on multiple levels. It is serving to create gender roles which constrict Bobby's ability to wear clothing that he likes because it is seen as inappropriate for his gender. In this example, being a girl is associated with being weak, which devalues being a woman. The direct effect of this system of oppression is violence toward Bobby, but it may also affect his confidence in his identity.

scenes.title: Privilege
scenes.description:
Professor Crenshaw starts to explain the term, Privilege. Before the Professor can finish her thought, Tom, a 12-year-old boy seated towards the front of the class, interrupts her and says, Privilege is like a backpack that is filled with tools… He continues on reciting the definition of Privilege previously given by the Professor. Professor Crenshaw allows him to finish.

That is correct," she replies, now, take a moment to think about what happened. You interrupted me. I'm not mad about this; actually, I think this is going to help me explain this topic. The professor then turns to the rest of the class, '' I want you all to take a moment to think about whether you interrupt all teachers equally or if you tend to interrupt women teachers more? Do you think my race enters into the picture? Do you suppose there is a difference between how you respond to black women as opposed to white or Asian women, or black men or white or Asian men? Perhaps if I was a black male teacher, you would interact with me differently, given that I face oppression due to my race, yet experience privilege due to gender. The class reflects upon male privilege.

The class discusses how men often interrupt women in conversation due to society teaching both men and women that men should be able to speak first. Thus, society gives men this privilege. Your male teachers likely do not have to worry about being interrupted as much as I do. This is just one example of how men can have male privilege though.

Professor Crenshaw says, "That's alright. It's not your fault, Tom, but it is your responsibility to help acknowledge and change this system. Tom suddenly begins to recall how he interacts with his teachers.

options.option: Unearned benefits that are bestowed upon some and not others because they have identities that are considered more desirable in a given culture.#correct
options.nugget: Good work. It is important to note that privilege is not something people actively see. Similar to someone born with less privilege, someone born with more privilege did not actually have control over receiving it. However, those with more privilege have the responsibility to use it to help fight for a more fair world where privilege doesn't exist.

options.option: Rights reserved for a defendant in court, such as privileged information
options.nugget: This is true in a court of law, but this is not quite what we are talking about here. Try again!

kc.question: True or false. It is often difficult to recognize our own privilege.

options.option: True #correct
options.nugget: Nice work! It is often harder to realize you have privilege than it is to know when you do not. People often assume that others have the same experiences as them, so they don't know that not everyone gets to do or think the same way they do. For instance, today, you can take antibiotics for bacterial infections that otherwise would be deadly. We all have this privilege now due to our identity of being alive in the 2000s, but if we were born 200 years ago, we would not have this privilege. Unless we think about it, it is easy to take privilege for granted.

options.option: False
options.nugget: It is actually often hard to recognize our own privilege. In fact, it is a skill we all need to build. You can take antibiotics today for bacterial infections that otherwise would be deadly. We all have this privilege now due to our identity of being alive in the 2000s, but if we were born 200 years ago, we would not have this privilege.

kc.question: Which of the following is an example of privilege?

options.option: A piece of candy given to someone when they behave.
options.nugget: This is a reward for acting in a certain way; as such, it can be considered earned. Privilege is something that is not earned. Try again!

options.option: Getting a good grade on a test after studying all week.
options.nugget: Getting a good grade on a test after studying is due to hard work. Privilege is something that is not earned. Now, if you were thinking that some people may not have to study as hard as others to get the same grade, this could be an example of having privilege due to one's intellect. Try again!

options.option: Getting paid for mowing your neighbor's lawn.
options.nugget: Getting paid for doing work is based on your effort. Privilege is something that is not earned. Try again!

options.option: Getting a car for your 17th birthday because it is a ritual in your family that everyone gets a car when they can drive. #correct
options.nugget: This was the correct answer, because receiving a gift like a car due to a ritual is not something you earned. Another family may be unable to have this ritual because of the expense. Therefore, this is a form of economic privilege.

scenes.title: Power
scenes.description: Professor Crenshaw starts to explain the term, Power. Power is an invisible force that can provide privilege to some people and oppress others simply based on their race, gender, or other identity, that they have no control over. Power can both come from privilege and oppression and result in further oppression and privilege. In order to make a change, people with more power need to realize when they have it, so that they can use it to give those with less power more.

options.option: Power is a force that people with minority identities have. This force causes them to obtain what they need in the world.
options.nugget: People with minority identities have less power. This decreased power can cause obstacles for people with minority or oppressed identities to obtain what they need in the world. Try again!

options.option: Power is an invisible force that can provide privilege to some people and oppress others simply based on their race, gender, or other identity, that they have no control over. Power can both be a result of privilege and oppression and can also result in further oppression and privilege. In order to make a change, people with more power need to realize when they have it, so that they can use it to give those with less power more. #correct
options.nugget: Nice work here! This is a tricky concept. Power can be caused by privilege and oppression and further perpetuate oppression and privilege.

options.option: Power is a term used to describe when one person takes advantage of another.
options.nugget: Although this can be a use of power, power related to intersectionality does not necessarily mean that one person is purposefully taking advantage of another. Many people do not recognize that they have more power in a given situation. Sometimes, power, by itself, is not necessarily a bad thing. However, negative effects can arise when one does not acknowledge or realize they have power. Power can cause damage to another when someone does not know they have more power in a given situation. Try again!

kc.question: Which of the following is true?

options.option: Julia is a white, straight, 12-year-old girl described by her friends as very pretty. She has an easy time making new friends. Her friend Bethany is also a white, straight, 12-year-old girl. People tend to think Julia is prettier than Bethany and Bethany has a more difficult time making friends. When Julia and Bethany go to parties, Julia often reports having a much better time than Bethany. In this example, Julia has more power than Bethany when it comes to social situations.
options.nugget: This is a situation in which power is at play. Julia experiences more power in a social setting than Bethany because others find her more attractive. There is a classic effect called the Halo Effect in which others tend to rate those considered conventionally attractive higher on other aspects than those who are not considered as attractive. Julia can be aware of her power and use it for good by trying to include Bethany in social activities. This example is true, but there is another answer that is also true. Good work! Try again!

options.option: Dominique can take the stairs that lead to the front of the school building whenever she wants. There is only one ramp to the school building and it is at the back of the school. As this entrance is further from the classrooms, she takes the easier route at the front of the school. In this example, Dominique has more power than someone that cannot walk.
options.nugget: This is an example of power operating. Because Dominique has no physical disability, she can have more choices regarding the entrance to the school she uses. This may not seem like a big deal, but it can have multiple impacts. When Dominique is late to class, she can save time by entering through the front of the building. This can save her time, but also reduce her emotional worry. Another student who has a mobility disability, such as being in a wheelchair, would not be able to enter the same way; there is a limitation placed on them. This can be corrected by creating an accessible ramp at the front of the school. Although this might appear like a minor inconvenience, imagine having to deal with this inconvenience in multiple settings and throughout your whole life. In this way, Dominique's able bodied privilege gives her more power than someone with a physical disability in this setting. Dominique has more power than a student in a wheelchair when it comes to entering the school. This example is true, but there is another answer that is also true. Good work! Try again!

options.option: Tammy and Jack are both in English class about to take a quiz. They are both considered star students by their teacher and had the same score on a recent standardized test. They are each given 30 minutes to complete the test.
options.nugget: This is not necessarily an example in which power is at play. If one of them was thought of more highly by their teacher than the other even though they were equally as good at English, power might be at play. However, in this example, only their merit is being assessed. Try again!

options.option: Both options 1 and 2 are correct.#correct
options.nugget: Nice work! You correctly identified how power was operating in both of these examples. Sorry to trick you there!

scenes.title: Putting It All Together
scenes.description:
Now that you have a basic understanding of how privilege, oppression, and power interact, let's focus on how these three concepts can change depending on your environment. A single identity can be privileged in one setting and oppressed in another. Look at this scene and see how privilege, oppression, and power can change depending on your environment. Take note of how based on your identity and power in a situation, you can help someone in a setting where their identity is oppressed. Having this empathy can help make you more aware of what may be happening to someone else and can put you in a position to help.

Joan is a lesbian and a student at Green Hill Middle, but she doesn't have many friends and doesn't know anyone else at school who is gay. Being the only lesbian at school makes her feel alone, so she decides to attend a meeting of Green Hill Middle's Gay Straight Alliance (GSA). The meeting is meant to connect students with similar gender identities. Joan hopes she may get to know other LQBTQ+ students and become a part of their community. When she gets to the meeting, there are quite a few other students there, and they all seem to be friendly, but they are also all boys. Despite finally being among other gay students, Joan feels intimidated being the only lesbian and girl. John, a gay boy and student, is talking with a few other guys. He notices Joan, the only girl at the meeting, standing alone and approaches her.

Hey, I'm John. Would you like to come over and meet some of the members of our group? Joan suddenly looks relieved by the offer.

Yes, that'd be great. I was starting to feel like I didn't belong here. My name's Joan, by the way. The pair walk over to a group of guys talking together, and John introduces Joan. They talk for about 20 minutes, and Joan gets more comfortable being the only girl there after talking with others in the LGBTQ+ community. Joan looks past John as they are talking and notices Abe walking into the large room. Abe too quickly feels uncomfortable after looking around the room and seeing they are the only one wearing a nonbinary name tag. They had hoped to connect with other LGBTQ+ students and not feel as isolated as they do in school, sometimes for being nonbinary. Joan notices Abe standing alone, glancing at all the name tags of others as they walk by.

Will you excuse me? I'll be right back, she says to the group before walking to Abe.

Hey, I see you here by yourself, but you're obviously here for a reason, like the rest of us."
scenes.nugget: Many things are happening in this scene. We see how different genders have different forms of privilege associated with them and how this privilege will change depending on the setting. Sometimes privilege takes the form of having others who look like you. Having more young men in a space might have given John a feeling of comfort, which Joan did not have access to because of her gender identity as a young woman. It is important to note that no one did anything wrong. However, John was able to use his privilege and power as a young man among a group composed of mostly young men to help Joan feel more included. Joan then used her privilege to help Abe, who might have felt uneasy because they were the only out nonbinary person. She thus used her cisgender (someone who identifies with the gender they were assigned at birth) privilege that everyone else in the meeting had to include Abe. Her same female identity that was previously oppressed was now privileged because of the change in environment, and she was able to use this privilege to empower someone else.
